metadata.title: Computational Electrostatics Predict Variations in SARS-CoV-2 Spike and Human ACE2 Interactions

abstract.text: SARS-CoV-2 is a novel virus that is presumed to have emerged from bats to crossover into humans in late 2019. As the global pandemic ensues, scientist are working to evaluate the virus and develop a vaccine to counteract the deadly disease that has impacted lives across the entire globe. We perform computational electrostatic simulations on multiple variants of SARS-CoV-2 in complex with human angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) variants to examine differences in electrostatic interactions across the various complexes. Calculations are performed across the physiological pH range to also examine the impact of pH on these interactions. Two of six SARS-CoV-2 variations having greater electric forces at pH levels consistent with nasal secretions and significant variations in force across all five variants of ACE2. Five out of six SARS-CoV-2 variations have relatively consistent forces at pH levels of the lung, and one SARS-CoV-2 variant that has low potential across a wide range of pH. These predictions indicate that variants of SARS-CoV-2 and human ACE2 in certain combinations could potentially play a role in increased binding efficacy of SARS-CoV-2 in vivo.

body_text.text: SARS-CoV-2 (CoV-2) is the latest novel coronavirus to have crossed the species boundary into humans over the past twenty years [7, 17] . Currently available information strongly suggests an originating source of the CoV-2 virus to be the bat coronavirus SL-CoV-RaTG13 with 96% similarity to CoV-2 [16] .

The World Health Organization (WHO) declared CoV-2 a public health emergency on January 30, 2020 and then pandemic status in the weeks following. WHO utilizes a tool to distinguish diseases based on the potential to bloom into epidemic/pandemic proportions and the availability of countermeasures to focus research and development (R&D) resources accordingly [14, 15] .

We have previously performed extensive research using electrostatic analysis of HIV gp120 envelope glycoprotein interactions with human CD4 and broadly neutralizing antibody proteins [5, 6, [9] [10] [11] [12] . Electrostatics are a novel way to evaluate protein interactions at the structural level with a focus on how environmental conditions, like pH, effect binding efficacy. * Center for Computational Science † Department of Computer Science

Although the focus has been HIV, the processes can easily be adapted to any domain for which molecular interactions may be altered by modulating pH. The theoretical approaches have been further extended to predict electric force (Coulombs Law) modulation by pH using the same set of data generated by the electrostatic surface charge (ESSC) pipeline [8, 12] .

For this research we utilized CoV-2 's1' proteins: 6LZG_B, 6M17_E, 6VW1_2, 6W41_C, QIS30425.1, QIS60489.1 and angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) proteins: AAQ89076.1, BAG37592.1, BAJ-21180.1, EAW98891.1, XP_011543854.1 obtained through sequence similarity searches such as NCBI Protein BLAST and the Protein Data Bank [2] . Structurally, CoV-2 shares similar traits with SARS-CoV that emerged in 2003 with a major point of difference being an additional cleavage in the spike protein sub-unit 's1' [13] making the substitution of similar SARS-CoV species difficult to justify in modeling and simulation work.

Computational methods of the pipeline performed as expected on CoV-2, but some analysis methods returned results that differed in content greatly when compared to those of HIV gp120. Where electrostatic fingerprinting (EFP) exposes structural displacement around the CD4 binding interface of HIV gp120 to produce a difference in electrostatic charges across the proteins surface area; the 's1' subunit of CoV-2's envelope spike assembly is a concise binding interface and structurally stable as indicated by the EFP in Figure 1 . This graph shows minor fluctuations across zero with most activity associated with lower pH values is likely caused by denaturing of the protein. Some evidence of fluctuation can be observed around the pH range of nasal secretions indicated by the red bar near the top and ranging from pH 5.5 to 6.5 [4] . The yellow bar indicates inflamed nasal secretions (rhinitis) pH from 7.2 to 8.3 [4] and blue indicates the approximate lung pH listed as 7.38 to 7.43 [3] , however, the graphs scale in 0.1 increments and displays the range as pH 7.3 to 7.5.

Application of the Adaptive Poisson-Boltzmann Solver (APBS) [1] to derive the binding energies (BE) provided similar results to EFP as the two methods are closely related. The same comparison with HIV gp120 BE results can be made here with the same explanation previously described. We present results with the most and least activity across the physiological pH range in Figure 2 . Again, most of the information derived is basically flat with the exception of lower pH as previously described.

EFP and BE results predict that no or minimal differences exist in binding efficacy across the physiological pH range for CoV-2. These predictions indicate a wide range of binding opportunities in vivo that may explain the broad range of symptoms observed during the pandemic. Predictions show some variation across pH ranges associated with respiratory systems to indicate the need to investigate the data in different ways. We expand the analysis with an alternative approach to electrostatic fingerprinting by taking the absolute values of the difference between 's1' and ACE2 unbound conformation ESSC pipeline data. We present results containing the highest and lowest potential differences from pH 4.5 to 9.0 in Figure 3 . This data shows an electric potential difference exists of varying quantity across all complex combinations evaluated. Furthermore, the pipeline data predicts that 's1' of CoV-2 is positively charged throughout the pH range while ACE2 has a transition to negative between pH 4.5 and 5.0 as show in Figure 4 . This knowledge allows the application of fundamental physics to express the results in terms of electric force.

By applying Coulombs Law to obtain the Electric Force ( ) in Newtons ( ), that either repel or attract two masses, we can graph the changing forces across the pH range of 3.0 to 9.0 in 0.1 increments to clearly represent the potential forces involved with two molecules at a distance of (10Å). Our model is non-specific in that specific interactions involve close-proximity contacts between proteins such as hydrogen bonds, unlike charges, and hydrophobic residue stacking. However, non-specific interactions are not closeproximity, and can be attractive or repulsive beyond the range of 3 angstroms or more. Electric force is a good example of the latter case. Details of the calculation are provided in the Methods section below. Figure 5 is a graph of all complexes that displays the Electric Force from pH 3.0 to 9.0 in 0.1 increments. Positive values indicate a repulsive force and negative values indicate an attractive force. We discard the repulsive forces on the basis that they exist outside the relevant pH range and the amplitude reduces clarity of the significant results. Figure 6 is the same information provided by Figure 5 with the repelling forces clipped. From this representation we can see unique characteristics emerging where a group of complexes stand out from the rest with low potential energy in a smooth curve across the examined range; another cluster of complexes emerges with a higher level of force in a slightly more erratic curve across the range and a group of complexes with a pronounced peak in force across the range of nasal secretions that peaks in the approximate middle.

While more details can be obtained from Figure 6 , a clear understanding is provided by Figure 7 grouped by 's1. ' Clear patterns emerge that indicate higher forces presents for 's1' proteins 6LZG_B Figure 6 : Aggregation of electric force for all complexes analyzed minus repulsive forces. This representation allows for a broad interpretation of the data where a single group of complexes stands out from the rest and another group has large spikes at nasal secretion pH levels. and 6W41_C at nasal secretion pH. Additionally, ACE2 genetic variations AAQ89076.1 and EAW98891.1 are most impacted by these two 's1' variants. However, 6M17_E, QIS30425.1, and QIS60489.1 have nominal forces across the interesting pH range with marginal differences among ACE2 variants. 6VW1_2 has low potential across the pH range and little differences across ACE2 variants.

Our results clearly predict that variations of CoV-2 directly impact the attractive forces involved between 's1' and ACE2. Furthermore, these results implicate human ACE2 variations that exacerbate those forces for specific 's1' and ACE2 combinations. Additionally, we point out that three groupings emerge in this analysis showing two 's1' variants with large spikes in force at pH 5.5 to 6.5 associated with nasal secretions. Three 's1' variants have a relatively smooth curve at nominal forces and one variation has a smooth curve with low force and minimal differences across ACE2 variations. While we are limited in the available crystal structures required to analyze through our pipeline, the current level of diversity allowed for detailed analysis adequate to express differences that expose potential alignments of increased force for certain combinations of CoV-2 and ACE2 variants. Additional crystal structures for other CoV-2 and ACE2 variants would allow for more precise predictions in these specific cases.

An analysis of the same nature at the amino acid level would provide more detailed predictions at specific regions involved with 's1' and ACE2 contact points and will be the subject of future studies.
We provide access to the full set of graphs generated from this data as a tar package located at: SARS-CoV-2
All computational methods related to the electrostatic pipeline are detailed in [5, 6, [9] [10] [11] [12] . For the specific calculation of Electric Force, APBS returns a factor for in:
Where is voltage of the system per unit, is the Boltzmann's constant: 1.3806504 E-23 − 1, is the temperature in Kelvin and is the charge of an electron: 1.60217646 E-19 C.
For the calculation of Electric Force ( ) we have:

Where is the Electric Force in Newtons, is Coulombs constant: 8.987551E+09, 1 is the charge in Coulombs of the first mass, 2 is the charge in Coulombs of the second mass, and is the distance in Meters between the two masses.

To derive Coulombs of charge from APBS requires a simple transposition of the terms and and multiplication of the results with values returned by APBS. For this model, the variables required to complete the calculations are: = 310 and = 10Å.

FIGREF0.text: Typical electrostatic fingerprint of 's1' subunit of CoV-2 envelope spike. Color bars near the top indicate the pH range of human nasal secretions (red), inflamed nasal secretions (yellow) and lung pH (blue). the fingerprint is basically flat from pH 5.0 and up indicating a stable structure Predicted electrostatic contribution to binding energy across the physiological pH range shows some activity around nasal and lung pH levels in the most active plot (top), while a nearly flat result across the interesting range of pH 5.0 to 8.5 is observed in the most inactive plot (bottom). Bars near the top represent normal nasal secretions (red), inflamed nasal secretions (yellow) and lung pH (blue).

FIGREF1.text: Comparison of potential differences between 's1' and ACE2 at result extremes contrasting the highest potential differences (top) with the lowest (bottom). Color bars indicate normal nasal secretion pH (red), inflamed nasal secretions (yellow) and lung pH (blue)

FIGREF2.text: Typical APBS results for 's1' (top) and ACE2 (bottom). In all cases, 's1' never crosses zero while ACE2 always transitions into negative values. Color bars indicate normal nasal secretion pH (red), inflamed nasal secretions (yellow) and lung pH (blue)

FIGREF3.text: Aggregation of electric force for all complexes. Positive values are repulsive and negative values are attractive.

TABREF0.text: 6VW1_2Figure 7: Grouped by 's1', patterns emerge that indicate higher forces for 's1' proteins 6LZG_B and 6W41_C at nasal secretion pH and distinct bias for ACE2 variants AAQ89076.1 and EAW98891.1, a lesser bias for ACE2 BAJ21180.1 and BAG37592.1. CoV-2 variants 6M17_E, QIS30425.1, and QIS60489.1 have nominal forces across the interesting pH range with marginal differences among ACE2 variants. 6VW1_2 has lower forces across the pH range and little differences across ACE2.
